title: Elementary proof that a non-orientable manifold of real dimension 2 does not admit a quasi-complex structure.

So by the Newlander-Nirenberg theorem, 𝑋 admits a complex structure, and complex manifolds have to be orientable.

However, the Newlander-Nirenberg theorem is a deep theorem and feels a bit overkill. Also I don't really see why there cannot be a quasi-complex structure. Is there a more elementary proof to convince myself?

title: Riemann's definition of the zeta function
body:
I am having trouble understanding Riemann's definition of the zeta function, and I will need to give a brief summary here before I can get to my question.

In his 1859 paper, Riemann derived the integral representation 𝜁𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑛11superscript𝑛𝑠1Γ𝑠superscriptsubscript0superscript𝑥𝑠1superscript𝑒𝑥1differential-d𝑥 that is valid for Re𝑠\gt1, and then modified the integral in order to define a function that is defined for all complex values of 𝑠, except 𝑠1, where it has a simple pole. The extension is given by 𝜁𝑠Γ1𝑠2𝜋𝑖subscript𝐶superscript𝑧𝑠superscript𝑒𝑧1𝑑𝑧𝑧 where 𝐶 is a "Hankel contour", that is, a path that travels from at a small distance italic-ϵ above the positive 𝑥-axis, circles around the origin once in counterclockwise direction with a small radius 𝛿, and returns to traveling at distance italic-ϵ below the positive real axis. Taking the limit as →italic-ϵ0 and →𝛿0 one can see that the integral subscript𝐶superscript𝑧𝑠superscript𝑒𝑧1𝑑𝑧𝑧 becomes superscript𝑒𝑖𝜋𝑠superscript𝑒𝑖𝜋𝑠superscriptsubscript0superscript𝑥𝑠1superscript𝑒𝑥1differential-d𝑥 and then the rest follows easily from known identities satisfied by the Gamma function. While the original real integral over 0 is clearly divergent if Re𝑠1, the contour integral over 𝐶 is defined for all complex 𝑠, because the path stays away from the singularity at 𝑠0 and from the branch cut along the positive 𝑥-axis.

My problem is understanding why the integral over 𝐶 does not depend on italic-ϵ and 𝛿, so that we can keep them at a safe positive distance from the singularities for the definition, but we can take the limit for the purpose of evaluating the integral. I know that by Cauchy's theorem we can modify a path of integration (without changing the value of the integral) starting and ending at the same point as long as we do not cross any singularity, but this path starts and ends at infinity, so I am not sure how to rigorously proceed using Cauchy's theorem. Even if I start the path at 𝑅𝑖italic-ϵ and end it at 𝑅𝑖italic-ϵ for some large 𝑅, the path starting and ending points change as italic-ϵ changes.
